element_texts.text: Completed

By virtute of an order from Headquarters of the District of Colorado, issued 1st February 1865, a Military Commission was convened at Denver City, Colorado, 9th February 1865, to investigate the conduct of the late Colonel J. M. Clivington, 1st Regt. Colorado Cavalry, in his recent campaign against the Indians, in the months of October, November and December 1864. From an examination of the record of the proceedings of the commission it appears, that in June 1864, John Evans, Governor of Colorado, and ex officio Superintendent of Indian Affairs, issued a proclamation addressed to "the friendly Indians of the plains," reciting several depredations and outrages committed by certain bands of Indians who were making war against the United States, and inviting all such as were disposed to be peaceable and friendly to keep away from the hostile bands, and come in to certain designated forts of the United States the commanders of which would afford them protection and furnish
Completed

furnish them with provisions. Copies of this proclamation were sent by Governor Evans to S.G. Colby, Indian Agent for the Arapahoes and Cheyennes, and he found means to distribute them among the Chiefs of those tribes. On the 4th September 1864, a small party of soldiers, approaching Fort Lyon, Colorado Territory, fell in with, (man that?) fort, and carried in as prisoners, "One Eye" and "Min-im-ie," Cheifs of the former. On being carried before Major E.W. Wynkoop, commanding the post, they were found to be messengers from the principal chiefs of the Cheyennes and Arapahoes, bearing a letter from them prepared by a half breed Indian, addressed to S.G. Colby, Indian Agent, expressing a strong desire for peace, and proposing in proof of their sincerity - to give up certain white captives, which they said were in their possession. Major Wynkoop appears to have made immediate preparation to rescue the captains mentioned, and on the 6th November, with 127 mounted men, commenced a march to Smokey Hill, where the Indians
Completed

Indians were said to be assembled. After four days march, his command reached the site of an Indian village near Smokey Hill, where he found a body of 700 or 800 Warriors, who must have been advised of his approach, for they were in line and had removed their women and children. He halted and sent forward "One Eye" to communicate with them, on which they fell back. He encamped on the bank of a creek, and soon "Black Kettle", principal chief of the Cheyennes, with other chiefs of the tribe, and the principal chief of the Arapahoes, held a council with him, some of his officers being also present. The chiefs complained that they had been unjustly treated; that the white men had not kept faith with them, but had made pretexts for robbing & killing their people, and when their young men retaliated they were charged with being the agressors. They had now little hope of making a good and permanent peace, but they had resolved to try, and therefore had written to Mr. Colby, and were now willing to make any submission required, and to give up their captives - of whom they said they had even
Completed

seven women and children  - if thereby they could secure a good peace. Major Wynkoop told them he was not empowered to make a treaty of peace with them; that he was not "big Chief enough", but that, if they would take a delegation of them to Denver to hold Council with the Governor, and would do all in his power to secure peace for them. "Black Kettle" was disposed to accept this proposal, but some of the other chiefs were not willing to submit, unless they could be assured of peace. Major Wynkoop again told them he could make no absolute promise but would be responsible for their protection and security in going to Denver, and for their safe return. The council broke up without coming to any conclusion, and Major Wynkoop removed his camp back some twelve miles, toward Fort Lyon, and then awaited the decision of the Chiefs. On the next day "Black Kettle" came to his camp
Completed

camp, bringing four of the captains, and said that the other three having been sold to the "Sioux", were at a distance but he had sent to recover them and would bring them in as soon as possible: that this council of Chiefs had decided to do as he should think best, and that he had determined to go with a delegation of chiefs to Denver as Major Wynkoop had proposed - trusting in his good faith to protect them in their return to their own people if they failed to secure peace. "Black Kettle" and seven other chiefs - representing all the tribes assembled at Smokey Hill - with their families, numbering about fifty persons, went, under this arrangement, to Fort Lyon with Major Wynkoop's command, and the Chiefs went thence with him to Denver where they held a council with Governor Evans. Before entering into council with the Chiefs, Gov. Evans told Major Wynkoop, in reply to his earnest advice to make peace with these Chiefs, who had so far acted in good
Completed

good faith, and would in his opinion continue to do so, that he was not at that time disposed to make peace with them, as he did not think they had been sufficiently punished; and besides, that in consequence of the depredations committed by some small bands of those Indians, in the Spring and early Summer, he had written to Washington for authority to raise more troops to pursue and punish them, and a Regiment of Cavalry had been enlisted for one hundred days, and was nearly ready for the field. If peace were now made, there would be nothing for these troops to do, and it might be thought at Washington that he had misrepresented the necessity for raising them. The council was held, and there were present at it, besides Governor Evans & the Chiefs - two or three citizens of Denver, Colonel Chivington, Major Wynkoop, and other officers. The Governor told the Chiefs that they should have come in when he first issued his proclamation: that they had made war against the United States, and enumerated several different outrages which he charged them with
Completed

with having committed during the Spring and Summer. These the Chiefs acknowledged, and attempted to show how they had been provoked by white men, so that their young men could not be restrained, but they were interrupted by the putting of other questions, so that their recital was not heard. "Bull Bear" - one of the Chiefs - said in reply to the charges made by the Governor, that they did not want to complain; it was true that there had been war, but they now wanted peace, and were disposed to let bygones be bygones, and to submit to any terms presented to them, and had all along been trying to make peace. That as soon as the Governors proclamation reached them a letter of submission was prepared by the Chiefs of his tribe, and his brother undertook to delilver it at a military post, which he approached with signs of peace, but he was shot down and killed. For them to come to this Council, wsa like coming through fire. He expected to lose his own life, for he had little hope of
Completed

of peace, but he was wlling to make the same sacrifice his brother had made in attempting to secure it for his people. Governor Evans said that the matter was now in the hands of the military authorities, and he could make no peace with them. He advised their submission to military authority, and that they should bring in their people near the fort, and await the determination of their case at Head Quarters. On being asked by one of the Chiefs how they were to subsist if they left the Buffalo grounds? the Governor told them that it was a question for them to determine. He advised them to rely on Major Wynkoop who would protect them. Colonel Chivington said very little at the Council. He told one of the Chiefs that he was the "War Chief" who had military command of that region, that his business was to fight - not to make peace. He recommended to them submission, and said they must help to fight such Indians as remained hostile. The Chiefs said that they felt authorized not only to make peace for themselves, but to assume
Completed

assume that when the "Sioux", "Comanches", and other hostile tribes found that the "Cheyennes" and "Arapahoes" had made a treaty they also would submit: if not they were willing to help the white men in subduing them. The Chiefs returned to Fort Lyon with Major Wynkoop and were advised by him to call in their people near to the Post, and assured of his protection until he should receive instructions from General Curtis - to whom he had written. He promised to give them due notice of the result, whatever it might be. Numerous bands of Indians came in upon the pledge of Maj. Wynkoop to protect them to the number of 600 or 700 men women and children, and to such as were in need some rations were issued. About the 25th November Major Wynkoop was relieved of the command of Fort Lyon, by Major Anthony. A council was held with the Chiefs near the Post, at which Major Anthony told them, in the presence of Major Wynkoop, that he would fulfill all the pledges made to them by the latter; that he
Completed

he would protect them until orders were received from Gen'l Curtis, and would then give them due notice of the result. He continued for a few days to issue rations to the needy, as Maj. Wynkoop had done. He then told them he could furnish no more supplies, advised them to remove to Sandy Creek - about 18 miles distant - and there send out their young men for Buffalo. Captasin Soule of 1st Colorado Vols. testified before the commission, that a few days after Major Wynkoop had been relieved, being out with a scouting party about 15 miles above Fort Lyon, he met - to his great surprise - Col. Chivington, in command of about 1,000 mounted men, marching toward the Fort. That the Col. asked him whether his arrival was expected at the Post? whether any Indians were there, and how many? That he assured the Colonel in reply that nobody at the Fort  expected the arrival of such a force; that there were some Indians there who were friendly and were treated
Completed

as prisoners of war. That upon this the Colonel remarked "they wouldn't be so treated when he got there." James F. (Comb?), a resisdent near Ft. Lyon, had just left that post, and met Colonel Chivington's command marching toward it. The Colonel asked him many questions about the Indians near the Fort, and about Major Wynkoop - of whom he spoke sneeringly. When inquiring as to the number of Indians there, he said that "scalps were what he wanted", on which witness told him he could get four or five hundred down there, very easily, with his force, for the Indians were unsuspicious, and could all have been taken at any time by fifty men. This witness further said that at the close of this conversation the Colonel remarked, "I long to be wading in gore." Captain Soule further testified that when he found - after Col Chivington arrived at Fort Lyon, that it was his purpose to attack the Indians there, he caused notice to be given him that they were under a solemn pledge of protection from Major Wyncoop and also from Major Anthony. That
Completed

That he and other officers also remonstrated with Major Anthony - who had then joined Colonel Chivington's command - against attacking these Indians, and that the Major said in reply that he only pretended friendship with them until a sufficient force could be assembled to kill them all. That Col. Chivington said he "was in, for killing all Indians, and d__n any man who had sympathy for them." Lt. Cramer of 1st Col. Vols., testified that he also remonstrated with Col. Chivington before the attack, and told him that not only Maj. Wynkoop, but all his officers were bound in honor to redeem the pledge made to these Indians, by protecting them. Colonel Chivington replied that he "thought it right and honorable to use any means under God's Heavens to kill Indians, who themselves killed women & children, d__n any man that sympathised with them, that in his opinion both Maj. Wynkoop and witness had better quit the service." The Indians, by advise of Major Anthony, had encamped on Sandy
Completed

Sandy Creek. Their village consisted of over one hundred lodges, and numbered five or six hundred persons - about two thirds of whom were women & children. Colonel Chivington marched out in the night, his command consisting of 1st & 3rd Regts. Colorado Vols., and Major Anthony's Batallion from Fort Lyon. Reaching the Indian Village about sunrise on the morning of the 29th November, he halted his command and ordered "Strip for action." He then addressed to his command the words "I do not tell you to kill all ages and sexes, but I do tell you to look back on the fields of the Platte, where your mothers, brothers, and sisters, have been slain, and where their blood soaks the ground." An order was then given to advance. An American Flag was at this time observed flying over a lodge - afterwards found to be that of "Blk Kettle" - principal Chief of the Cheyennes, and a white flag was seen immediately afterwards. I.P. Beckwith, who accompanied the
Completed

the command, a guide testified that the troops advanced in some order, at first and as they approached the village. "White Antelope" - a chief - came running toward the advancing column, and cried out in English "Stop", :Stop" - throwing up his hands at the same time. Finding that he was not regarded, he folded his arms and stood untill he was shot down. He was scalped, and his body mutilated. As the troops continued to advance the women and children fled and tried to drive off a herd of stock from the rear of the village. John Smith, (unclear) Interpreter, was in the Indian Camp with one Londerback - an enlisted man - and another white man, when the attack was made. They had been permitted by Major Anthony to go there, a few days before, to trade with the Indians. They tried to get out - when they found the troops were really advancing for an attack - by twisting a white handkerchief and running out towards the column, but were fired
Completed

fired on, and driven back. Smith testified that when the attack was made, the village contained between 500 and 600 persons and that about two thirds of them were women and children - as has before been stated - and that there were not many warriors among them. He did not think thtat more than fifty or sixty made any resistance to the attack. The Indians fled up the creek, many of them in its bed, which was nearly dry - some of them returning the fire of the troops, as they retreated. The troops continuing to advance, soon broke and scattered themselves along the banks of the creek in a disorderly manner, firing across it from either side at the Indians in its bed or who attenmpted to conceal themselvves under its banks - thus endangering and wounding each other, and killing the Indians of all ages and both sexes without mercy. The slaughter was thus continued for three or four miles up the creek, and the fire did not entirely cease until 3 or 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Nearly - if not quite all
Completed

all the slain were scalped, as they fell and the bodies of many were horribly mutilated. It does not appear that any officer attempted to check these atrocious barbarities, but on the contrary - that one, at least, was an active participant in them. Sergeant Luther Palmer, of the 1st Colorado, testified that he saw Major Sayr take the scalp off the head of one Indian. "There was a long silver tail to it." 1st Lieut. Camron testified that "the privates of women" were cut out and stretched onto saddle bows and hat fronts, and so publicly worn in the ranks on the return march. Lieut. Camron was of a company of New Mexico Vols. Another witness testified that he saw the body of "One Eye" lyiing in the bed of the creesk. He had been scalped, his skull crushed in, and his privates cut out. The testimony as to the scalping and mutilation of the bodies of the dead was overwhelming. One witness declared that the spectacle presented by the battle field was so revolting that he "could not bear" to look
Completed

look over it for the purpose of counting the killed. Lieut. Camron further testified that a living infant - about two weeks old - was thrown into the feed-box of a wagon and carried one day on the return march, then thrown out on the road to perish. Another witness however stated that a squaw cut the throat of this infant and herself threw its body into the road. "Jack Smith", a half breed, son of John Smith, the interpreter, was murdered the next day after the attack, while under guard as a prisoner. Beckwith testified that "Jack" was shot while sitting in a lodge near him, a hole being first cut in a (wing?) of the lodge, so that a pistol could be levelled at him. Captain Soule testified that before "Jack" was killed, Lieut (Damm?) asked Col Chivington if he objected to his being killed, and that the Col. answered "You need not ask me that." It was shown that Col. Chivington was near the lodge in which "Jack" was confined when
Completed

when the murderous shot was fired, but it does not appear that any inquiry was made on the subject; nor does it appear from the testimony of any of the witnesses, that either Col. Chivington or any other officer attempted to check the fiendish attrocities committed during the day of the slaughter, or that after the advance had commenced, and the troops had scatterred themselves in a disorderly manner along the banks of the creek, that any order was issued to them either of recall, restraint or otherwise. All the witnesses - both for the prosecution and the defence -- agree in the statement that the Indian Village when attacked, consisted of something over 100 Lodges - their statements varying from a little over 100, to 120 - and those familiar with Indian habits agreed in the estimate of 5 persons to a lodge - or between 500 and 600 in all. The usual proportion of warriors in a full community of Cheyennes and Arapahoes was shown to be three to every two lodges, but as in this
Completed

this case bands of the young men were out on a Bufffalo hunt, the proportion was far less - and yet, Col.. Chivington - in his official report by telegraph to Maj. General Curtis - advised him under date of 29th November 1864 as follows: "I this morning at day-light attacked Cheyenne Village of 130 Lodges - from nine to ten hundred warriors strong: Killed Chiefs 'Black Kettle,' 'White Antelope,' 'Knock Knee', 'Little Robe', and betweeen four and five hundred other Indians." Stephen Decatur, a witness for the defence, also testified that on the day after the battle he counnted on the field the bodies of four hundred and fifty warriors, and that there were very few women and children killed. The other witnesses varied in their estimate of the number killed - one stating it as high as 180. John Smith - the Interpreter, who was in the village throughout the day - estimated the number at less than 100, but there was great uniformity of statement that about two thirds of the killed were women and children; that
Completed

that the killed were of all ages from infancy to 80 years - and were scattered all over the field extending three or four miles up the creek; that all, or nearly all, were scalped, and the bodies of a great many mutilated in the most horrible and revolting manner. The testimony of most of the witnesses for the defence had little relation to the affair at Sand Creek, but was mainly designed to show that Maj. Wynkoop's advance on Smoky Hill was imprudent and unauthorized. That several outrages had been committed by the Indians prior to the attack on them, and that Major Anthony had repeatedly said that if he could have raised a sufficient force, he would have destroyed these Indians before the arrival of Col. Chivington. Evidednce was also introdsuced to discresdit Capt. Soule, Lieut. Cramer, John Smith, and other witnesses for the Government, but without shaking the mass of evidence disclosing the atrocities at
Completed

at Sandy Creek. It was shown by the testimony that a very large number of ponies and mules, with many buffalo robes, and other property, were captured at the Indian Village, and that much of this property had not been duly accounted for, but had been appropriated by the officers and men of the command. Evidence was also introduced as to the equipment and supplying of the 1st Regiment Col. Vols. and the disposition made of its arms and equipments when mustered out of the service, but it is not deemed important to the purpose of this report to review these portions of the evidence.
Completed

W.H. Slack. Sir
Your unjust and ungentlemanly letter reached me yesterday, and should have received the silence it merits at my  hands, had it not contained some statements,- which I am forced to correct. First of all; although you sneer at my religious sentiment - which was in bad taste - it is pesrfectly sincere, and will alway prevent me from wronging any man by trying to step between him and his wife. I have wronged you  in no way. Since the day your wife informed me that you did not wish me to visit her, I have never crossed your threshold, communicated with your wife or daughter to see her. I have always remembered she was your wife - and an old friend who has never done anything to forfeit my respect Understand distinctly, Mr. Slack, I am not in love with your wife, as you infer - and I have never
Completed

taken advantage of her in any way, as you know. I am as worthy to take your hand to-day, as I was when we first met as friends at your table. Regrding my recent visit to Washington, I went there professionally, with no desire or intention of seeing your wife and when I met her through no volition of my own, I was given to understand that you knew I was in the city and had no objection to my seeing her. Now, regarding your statement that I was "dining and wining" with her. On each occasion when I met your wife at a dinner or luncheon, I was the guest of a society acquaintance, as was Mrs. Slack, and on every occasion I was accompanied by friends. Mrs. Slack never saw me alone and I fail to see how any lady can be compromised, as you state, by meeting a gentleman casually in the presence of five or six people.
Completed

I am writing dispassionately, but I am none the less indignant at the tone of your letter, and I think when your cooler judgement resumes its sway you will admit that you have been hasty and unjust. In conclusion, understand positively; I have no wish to hold any further communication verbal or written with your wife or yourself. If Mrs. Slack should cross my path in future, it will be entirely by accident and not of my desire or seeking. Referring to the last sentence of your letter, you have completely mistaken my character if you think to intimidate me or that I fear you, the instincts of honor which you aver I do not possess will keep me, as they have here to fore from anything a true gentleman should avoid. Your threat was not
Completed
only superfluous - but quite unworthy of the courage you have evinced in the past. My honor has never been questioned and I am as desirous as you are to avoid malicious gossip. Frederick Spaulding
Completed

At the Gate
St. Peter stood guard at the golden gate
With a solemn mien and an air sedate,
When up to the top of the golden stair
A man and a woman ascending there,
Applied for admission.  They came and stood
Before St Peter, so great and good,
In hope the City of Peace to win - 
And asked St. Peter to let them in.
The woman was tall and lank, and thin,
With a scraggly beardlet upon her chin.
The man was short, and thick, and stout,
His stomach was built so it rounded out.
His face was pleasant, and all the while
He wore a kindly and genial smile.
The choirs in the distance the echoes woke,
And the man kept still while the woman spoke.
"O, thou who guardest the gate" said she,
"We two come hither beseeching thee
To let us enter the heavenly land
And play our harps with angel band.
Of me, St. Peter, there is no doubt,
There's nothing from heaven to bar me out,
I've been to meeting three times a week,
And almost always I'd rise and speak.
I've told the sinners about the day
When they'd repent of their evil way,
I've told my neighbors - I've told them all
'Bout Adam and Eve, and the Primal Fall,
I've shown them what they'd have to do
Completed

If they'd pass in with the chosen few, I've marked their path fo duty clear, laid out the plan in, their whole, career, I've talked and talked to in loud and long, for my lungs are good, and my voice is strong; So, good St. Peter, you'll clearly see the fate of heaven is open for me, but my old man I regret to say, hasn't walked in exactly the manor way. He smoked and he swears, and grave faults he's got and I don't know whether he'll pass or not. 
"But oh, St Peter, I love him sr! To the pleasures of heaven please let him go! I've done enough-a saint I've been, won't that a time! Can't you let him in? By my grain goofed I know it is St that the ________  ______ fry below; But isn't there some way you can see that he may enter who is dear to me?"
It's a Masson ____ by which I pray, But the chosen effect to find or may of ______, or fooling, or _____ you so that  their relation may able through and say, St Peter it seems to me this grate isn't kept so it ought to be you ought to stand right by the opening, thus and never sit down in that easy chair
Completed

And say, St Peter my sight is damned but I don't like the way your _____ are ______ They're cut too wide, and outward tossed they'd look better ____ cut straight across. . Well, we must be going, our ___, to win, So open, St. Peter and we'll pass in!
St Peter sat quiet, stroked his staff, but spite of his office he had to laugh, Then he said with a fiery gleam in his eye, "Who's tending, this gateway you or I?" And then he rose in his statue tall, and pressed a button on whom the wall; and said to the ___ who answered the bell "Esent this lady around to-hades!"
The man stood still as a
Completed

St. Peter was silent. With head bent down 
He raised his hand and scratched his crown, 
Then seeming a different thought to take, 
Slowly, half to himself, he spake:
"Thirty years with that woman there?
No wonder the man hasn't any hair!
Swearing is wicked. Smoke's not good.
He smoked and swore -- I should think he would.
Thirty years with that tongue so sharp?
Ho! Angel Gabriel! Give him a harp!
A jeweled harp with a golden string!
Good sir, pass in where the angels sing!
Gabriel, give him a seat alone -

One with a cushion up near the throne!
Call up some angels to play their best,
Let him esnjoy the music and rest!
'See that on finest Ambrosia he feeds.
He's had about all the hades he needs
It isn't just hardly the thing to do
To roast him on earth and the future too"
They gave him a harp with golden strings,
A glittering robe, and a pair of wings,
And he said as he entered the Realm of Day,
Hell, this beats the Devil, anyway!"
And so the Sccriptures had come to pass
That "The last shall be first and the first shall be last."
Joseph Bert Smiley.
Completed

Rail Road Towns
For convenience of continuation of the Rail Road, as it pushes its way into the wilderness, some point is selected as the terminus for the line. This point becomes the Rail Road Depot. Here are collected the ties rails and material for the next eighty or hundred miles.
Passenger and freight being carried only to this point, it becomes the place of departure for stages, and for Frighters with their huge wagon, "The prairie schooner."
Houses go up as by magic. All insurance (?) business is done by these peripatetic merchants. On this point the grading contractors depend for the supplies for their working gangs yet in advance. To a visit to this "Town," the graders, tie cutters,
Completed

teamsters & hundreds of other employees look forward as the ne plus ultra of human felicity - Here congregate also gamblers - thieves and ruffians of high and low degree. Every  (unclear) and incentive to the wildest debauchery are offered. The Bar rooms, gambling saloon and dance houses are in the most gorgeous style of tinsel finery, and here the hard worked grader or the rough "bull whacker rejoices to exchange his hard earned dollars for what to him is a vision of paradise. There is no law but the will of the individual, modified in some degeree by the will of another individual, and when each will is supported and enforced by the inevietable six shooter, it is not surprising that their
Completed

Town should be understanding -
 Among as many towns on so many Rail Roads it is difficult to select any one as worthy of special immortality of unclear. At the risk however of being insidious, one or two must be mentioned.
 For jolly recklessness of life for utter indifference as to who "went under" for careless abandon and entire disregard of all the ordinary rules of self-preservation the town of Julesburg is worthy the palm. Situated by the Union Pacific Rail Road in the North East corner of the Territory of Colorado, and near the junction of Lodge Pole Creek with the South Platte River. This town attained
Completed

a population of about four thousand proper, and a celebrity as wide as the frontier. Every one seemed in a good humor and wore a smiling countenance and if the six shootin is just as deadly when "pulled" with a laugh as wide a frown, it is certainly no fault of the available actors in the tragedies-
Every day saw the burial 'with their boots on' of one or more unclear and the country was likely to become as populous as the Town, when the Rail Road establishes another Depot in advance, and Julesburg like the Ara. folds its tent & disappeared.
One small house (unclear R.R. Station) and one hundred and twenty seven graves of which six are natural deaths are all that remain to mark the site of the busiest
Completed

noisiest most rollicking and most tragic place ever developed even by the unclear unclear that goes to make an American Frontier scratched outpopulation --

 It is impossible to depict the unclear here of a homicide in Julesburg.
 It was martyrdom to gallop through the streets, the sound of the galloping feet instantly bringing to every door men, six shooter in hand who blazed away at the sides just to see if they could hit flying. One day the victim playing a quiet game of billiards in one of the extreme unclear across of the long principal street was attracted to the door by yells and shouts of vociferous laughter, and repeated piston shots -- a spare but powerfully built frontiers man, his third drunk mistook hat on
Completed

coat, mounted bare backed on a fine Indian pony went flying past. Reining in at the end of the street, he turned his horse and with a whoop of defiance yelled out. "You cant shoot worth a d- I'll give you another show. Fair plan, now - Dont shoot till I get started"- Bending low on the neck of his horse, he plunged in the spurs, dashed down the street through a perfect Balaclava of fire and noise.  and to the astonishment of every spectator escaped without a scratch. Though at least fifty shots were fired at him.
A crowd was one day collected on the street uproariously applauding the efforts of a half drunken man to stand on his head - a man in an adjacent saloon made a wager
Completed

that he could kill six men of that crowd before he himself would be disabled.
Depositing the stakes with the barkeeper, he went out, deliberately sat down on the ground within fifteen paces of the crowd, rested his revolver on his knee & hand, & opened fire. Before he had discharged his fourth shot, he was completely riddled with bullets. and while he was carried off to be buried, his antagonist in the bet invited the crowd in to drink the dead man's health, out of the stakes the barkeeper handed over to him. (it having been shown that the shooter had killed only two men)-
One night a huge seven-foot "Pike County" ruffian, arrived with a note. Pike is a county in the state of Missouri noted for the huge stature & rough demeanor of its inhabitants--
Completed

a gigantic revolver, walked into a drinking and gambling saloon & in a loud voice proclaimed himself "the best man in Wyoming Territory." As no one disputed the assumption he approached the different gambling tables & whenever he could catch an eye, he would present his cocked pistol and demand, "what have you got to say about it." Of course each man so interrogated would at once admit the championship of such an interrogator. In this way "Pike" went all around the room, and with strong expression in disparagement of the courage of the persons in the saloon, was about to leave when he caught the eye of one of two men who had just come in and were quietly taking a drink at the bar.
Walking up to this newcomer he thrust his six shooter in his face
Completed

with the rough demand "what have you got to say about it." Quick as thought the other drinking man sat down his glass pulled a wide-mouthed Derringer from his pocket stuck it in Pike's ribs and fired. "Pike" fell. The stranger put up his pistol, finished his drink, and then turning the body of the dead Pike over with his foot - said very quietly "that man would have killed somebody directly"-
Major B. a fat jovial German who had earned some distinction in the Volunteer service in the war of Rebellion, kept an eating house in Julesburg, which, as the viands were fair, the charges reasonable and the Major very courteous, did an excellent
Completed

business.  Though extremely amiable, & hospitably inclined the Major kept a sharp eye to his main chance and gave no credit, himself going around during each meal to collect "the stamps." One day a tall slender long-haired specimen came in and taking a seat proceeded to demolish everything eatable, within the reach of a wide pair of arms.

From birth to man's or woman's? estate? Indian life in common with the lives of all other people has three periods. infancy, childhood and youth. Among civilized people those periods merge gradually one with the other. Among these savages they are well marked, distinctly defined.
A short sketch of the first two periods is necessary to the full understanding of the springs? of action,which make the third the only truly romantic period of Indian life.
All Indians of whom I have knowledge are extremely fond of children, and unclear and unclear and spoil the babies until they become perfect little torments and pests, climbing climbing and troubling unreproved
Completed

14
over visitors in the lodge, or over the on his bed, where he may be trying to rest and sleep after a hard days unclear.
With - the women this fondness seems to be rather a general maternal instinct, than a positive love for their own offspring, for I have seen on several instances where Indian women have offered to "swap" their own babies for others whose appearance they liked better. Should a nursing child lose it's mother it is immediately adopted by all the nursing mothers of the band, and passed from hand to hand fairly? sumptuously?.
This love of children is so strong a peculiarity of Indian character, that even war parties, composed of warriors alone, each ready to inflict the utmost horror of torture
Completed

on every stranger he meets, will not infrequently take back to their village the little beings? they have ruthlessly slaughtered, and this frequently at great expense of care and trouble. These waifs are always received with great rejoicings, and at once adopted into the families of their captors, or with other families,  whose heads have taken a fancy to them. It not infrequently happens that they are adopted into families where there are already several children. To these they at once become become brothers or sisters, and in all cases are treated exactly as the other children. There is among these savages no fashionable prejudices against large families. On the contrary the greater the number of

children, the prouder are fathers and mothers. Owing to their hard life and constant drudging Indian women do not as a rule have many children, and most of the men have quite as many wives as children in the lodge. An old Sioux chief named Red Bear, who was a great friend of mine, had the unusual number of five children. Three girls and two boys, and he was never weary of boasting of them.Half a dozen times a day he would say, possibly to the same person, "See, I have only three wives yet I have five children. Three girls and two boys. Two splendid boys." 
Indian children are unclear punishment in any way. A father may whip his sons. Though this is extremely rare, and only in

flagrant cases of neglect when herding the ponies (the family wealth) or for petty thefts from members of the same band. The mother is never permitted to whip their son for anything, although she may punish him by pulling his hair or by refusing him food. I have never heard of an Indian father who slapped or otherwise punishes his daughter, except for the one single offense of refusing to live with a man to whom he had sold her as a wife. The mother may punish her daughter in any way, but it is seldom done.
There are among these people no arbitrary rules of manners and good breeding. No moral offenses. No thousand and one petty rules of life and conduct the violation of

A dozen or fifteen people (two or more families may all live in the one circular room of the lodge, rarely more than eighteen feet in diameter. Each does ass he or she pleases. The men may gamble or smoke or tell stories or sleep. The women may sew or sing or chatter like magpies. The children may tumble scream and play. No one is annoyed.

Jealousy of her husband seems to have no place in the organization of an Indian woman. Nor have I ever yet see the slightest jealousy of the children of the other wives. The real cause is, I think, that however sentimental and spooney? the youngster may be with his sweetheart or however devoted the husband may be to his wife or wives, there is never that love which recognizes equality of mind and station.

for woman, and which curiously enough seems to have been adopted by about every tribe of Indians  in the United States) is a drudge, a menial, a slave, and a coward. To call a warrior a "squaw" is the grossest of all insults, except that of being struck by a squaw. The warrior is head of his lodge, his sons are destined to be warriors and heads of lodges. They cannot be insulted and outraged by blows from a "squaw", even though she be his own mother.From their earliest years Indian boys are taught to regard all "squaws" as inferior beings, servants, minsters to their comfort and pleasure. The birth of a baby is the occasion of great rejoicing in an Indian family, though among the Cheyenne it is an expensive luxury. Among civilized people the god-father and god-mother are usually selected from personal affection, and a small present to the god-child is customary.
An illustration of the homogeneity of human thought is given in the fact that these savages though utterly ignorant of the Christian idea, or the symbolism expressed by the ceremony, have practically the same custom always having a man and woman to stand in loco parentis to the new born child. 
These are selected beforehand, generally persons as high in rank and influence as possible, and on whom the parents
Completed

23
wish to confer obligation. Religion and policies are both involved. On being notified of their selection the + note god father sends to the expectant mother a cradle as handsome and elaborate as his means or inclination permits, and over which "good medicine" has been made, that is it has been specially blessed by the good gods. The god-mother  sends a "medicine knife" (generally an ordinary wooden handled butcher's knife) which must be used to perform the necessary surgical operation on the child.
+(Note) It is not to be understood that the Indian designate these persons by terms translatable as god-father and god-mother. I use these appellations as the clearest Christian approach to the designation of individuals who are selected and expected to aid the new born child in his life in this world.
Completed

24
In return the expectant father sends presents far exceeding these in value. A rich man sometimes giving to each a half a dozen or more ponies. Indians are very free-hearted and liberal, and in his joy and pride in the new born baby the father not infrequently presents these "sponsors" with quite half his whole herd. But this was in the "good old days" when these Indians were free to roam at will, and to recruit there from white men or neighboring tribes, Since they have been confined to reservations the are much more economical, and at the present time the general custom among the southern Cheyenne is to give a pony to each sponsor. However poor the individual may be (and some of the more hostile of

the tribes have had all of their ponies taken away from them by the government) the parents always find something to give the "sponsor" more valuable than the presents they themselves receive.
In it's general form the cradle (or receptacle for the very young infant) is practically the same among all the tribes of whom I know.
The skin of some animal is cut to proper shape, and what is to be the back is securely fastened to a board - or in the most approved crale to two narrow strips of board, crossing each other in the form of an X, or fitted together in the form of an inverted A. Thus V.
The front of the skin is closed with lacing or by strings at intervals up to the very throat of the occupant. Bundled in
Completed

26
rags or soft skins, and for some months with even its arms swathed tightly to its body, the little one passes the first year of its life in this nest, being taken out only a few times a day for cleanliness.
To the board is fastened a strap of proper length to go over the head of the mother, and rest across her chest and shoulders.
I have described the general features of the cradle, but even ion the same tribe or band there are any two alike. Some are roughly made, without ornament and extremely dirty, others better, and yet other scrupulously neat and exceedingly beautiful in elaborate ornamentation. I presented one to the Smithsonian Institute, which had cradled a baby for a year yet was spotlessly clean, and ornamented
Completed

27
with more than thirty dollars worth of beads, worked skillfully in beautiful patterns, a marvel of patient pain-staking labor. There are no such things as "babies in arms" among Indians. When the mother is walking or riding the baby rides "pick-a-pack" with it's back to her, it's little black beady eyes peering curiously to the rear. When she is at home the cradle and it's occupant are laid on the bed or stood against the wall of the teepee, anywhere out of the way, When at out-door work she stands the cradle against a tree, or may be hangs it to a branch, where it dances? merrily in the wind.
In some of the northern tribes the cradles ar provided with hoods to protect the face of the child in very cold weather, and when
Completed

28
"baby begins to take notice" the mother will hang feathers and rattled in front of it's face for it's amusement.
Indian babies cry when they are hungry or sick. I have never seen a peevish fretful Indian baby such as I have seen tormenting white households almost beyond endurance. This is due partly to the fact that they are let alone. No bouncing on the knee of a rough nurse, no dosing with teas and soothing syrup, no being smothered with kisses one minute and having fingers poked into it's ribs the next; but principally to the fact that all useless complaining is foreign to the Indian nature because it is forbidden in the cradle. If a baby cries it's mother will try to discover if it it ailing, or wants
Completed

29
or needs anything, As soon as she has made up her mind that the crying indicates only temper she promptly suppresses it. Seizing the baby the nose with her thumb and index finger she closes the palm of her hand over it's mouth. When it's struggles indicate that it is pretty nearly suffocated she releases it.
If the first application fails of success, as it generally does, for the new and disagreeable sensation makes baby forget what it was crying about - it is again and again Each time more vigorous in application, until this "moral suasion" effects a complete cease of any disposition to cry for nothing.
To me Indian babies look so much alike that I have often wondered whether the mother would discover it if some mischievous urchin
Completed

30
should exchange a couple, putting each into the cradle of the other. Some time ago I saw in a newspaper that this trick had been perpetrated upon a number of American mothers, who assembled for a tea party had left their babies all in one bed room - to which some mischievous  youngster gained access and so exchanged the clothing of the babies, that the mothers in spite of their maternal instincts and knowledge of the sex of their babies were so confused that some of them went home very uncertain as to whether they carried their own offspring or not.

This curious separation of the sexes is a peculiarity of Indian life, and though a man may have several wives, he never looks to these for companionship. When two or three men get together for a chat the women generally keep away.The sexes have ^eachᵥ it's own games, sports, accouterments, though in certain gambling games both sexes take part. In their social dances, men and women dance together, but a man never accompanies his wife to or from a dance, and it would be a gross breach of decorum did she accept the escort of any other man. The men go alone or together as suits them; the women in bevies, under the escort and guardianship of some staid old matron.

Cambridge, Mass.
Oct. 30, 1877
My dearest -
Your of 2nd? last? July to hand read with great interest. I am pleased to find that we are in harmony in respect - to the general question of migrations of Bisons.
I have time now for only a word about the “Mountain” Bison. My views are quite fully expressed in relation to this supposed “race”, “variety”, or “species”, as variously considered by different persons, at pp. 447, 448 of Hayden's reprint. I have given this question careful attention, have examined and measured specimens in various parts of South Park, Col. and the
Completed

neighboring country, I am fully convinced that the so called “Mountain Bisons” are merely remnants of the herds that at one time ranged continuously from the plains throughout the parks & valleys of the Rocky Mts. Whence to the neighboring county beyond, and that their difference in habits to their respects are due wholly to peculiarities of surroundings. I have traced their remains to far above timber-lines on Mt. Lincoln & neighboring peaks. I have as yet been unable to find two persons that agree as to their distinctive peculiarities as compared with the Bisons of the plains. While different persons assign to them the most diverse characteristics. A long
Completed

residence in the mountains & isolation would tend in time to produce slight modifications of ? & size as well as of habits.
Very ? yours,
